resources.string: Please submit the form to seek training advice, tips, and guidance on how to improve your badminton techniques and tactics.

We aim to create a mobile learning platform for badminton enthusiasts, providing professional and advanced training guidance and support to players at various skill levels to improve badminton techniques and tactics. \nOur app is authentic information-based, which is straightforward, educational, and easy to use. \nWe provide a multifunctional seamless learning environment that enables users to have “coaches” whenever and wherever they play.
The One and Only Professor and Doctoral Advisor in Badminton in China\nWinner of Women\'s Singles and Women\'s Doubles of the 2000 National Capital ("DC") Open
The Founder and Head Coach for New York City Badminton Club\nThe Certified National Badminton Coach in the US
Former Professional Player\nThe Successor of the World-Renowned Tang Style Badminton Training
CIPUTRA HANOI - YONEX SUNRISE Vietnam International Challenge 2020
5. Back court hitting position, Forehand slice technique
11. Effective Footwork, Hit a proper drop shot
13. Hit a fast and tight slicing drop shot from backcourt
14. Improve the forehand push-shot from forecourt
16. The details of quick, Efficient movement
Location: Dodge Physical Fitness Center \nAddress: 3030 Broadway, New York, NY 10027

- 1996 – present: Founder and Head coach for NYC Badminton Club

 - 2015: Head coach for Pan American Team

 - 2014: USAB Certified HIGH PERFORMANCE COACH Level 4

 - 2003: 1st place in Men’s Doubles in BOSTON OPEN.

 - 2002: 1st place in Men’s Single in BOSTON OPEN.

 - 2000: 1st place in Men’s Doubles and Mixed Doubles, 3rd place in Men’s Single in USA National Championship.

 - 1997: as replacement coach for USA Olympic Team at Olympic Training Center in Colorado Spring.

 - 1992 – 1996: Head coach for Spain National Olympic Team.

 - 1992: Award as International Sports Master by China National Sports Federation.

 - 1987 – 1992: Member of China National Team.

1. When the leading score reaches 11 points, players have a 60 second interval.

2. A 2 minute interval between each game is allowed.

3. In the third game, players change ends when the leading score reaches 11 points.

1. A match consists of the best of 3 games of 21 points.

2. Every time there is a serve - three is a point scored.

3. The side winning a rally adds a point to its score.

4. At 20 all, the side which gains a 2 point lead first, wins that game.

5. At 29 all, the side scoring the 30th point, wins that game.

6. The side winning a game serves first in the next game.

1. At the beginning of the game (0–0) and when the server’s score is even, the server serves from the right service court. When the server’s score is odd, the server serves from the left service court.

2. If the server wins a rally, the server scores a point and then serves again from the alternate service court.

3. If the receiver wins a rally, the receiver scores a point and becomes the new server. They serve from the appropriate service court – left if their score is odd, and right if it is even.

1. A side has only one ‘service’.

2. The service passes consecutively to the players as shown in the diagram.

3. At the beginning of the game and when the score is even, the server serves from the right service court. When it is odd, the server serves from the left court.

4. If the serving side wins a rally, the serving side scores a point and the same server serves again from the alternate service court.

5. If the receiving side wins a rally, the receiving side scores a point. The receiving side becomes the new serving side.

6. The players do not change their respective service courts until they win a point when their side is serving.
Please type in your report code here
"Location: Dodge Physical Fitness Center Address: 3030 Broadway, New York, NY 10027 "

- Professor, Capital University of Physical Education and Sports Graduate School

 - Former National Badminton Player, Master Athlete

 - 1986 Dutch WorldBadminton Open (First Place, Women’s Singles)

 - 1986 Belgian World Badminton Open (First Place, Women’s Singles)

 - 2000 Washington DC Badminton Open (First Place, Women's Singles. First Place, Women's Doubles)

 - Head Coach of IBF World Training Center

 - Supervising Professor of International Olympic Committee

 - Badminton Committee Member of Chinese Sports Vocational Skill Evaluation Expert Instructors Committee

 - 2016 Awarded the title of “Outstanding Trainer of National Vocational Qualification in Sports Industry”, awarded by the General Administration of Sport of China

 - Screenwriter and the coach of demonstration and explanation in Badminton – Instruction from Experts, created by Chinese Central Television in 2006.

\nSonghua Tang is the successor of the world- renowned Tang-style badminton training, as the son of Xianhu Tang, who has led and accompanied the Chinese Badminton team in many successful campaigns at the Olympics, World Championships, and Asian Games since 1980s, and was inducted into the International Badminton Federation Hall of Fame in 2002. \n
